prosody.p: Welcome back to Community Signal, where we explore the stories, systems, and sparks that shape our schools, towns, and futures.
I’m Jason—township clerk, technologist, and someone who believes that infrastructure is more than fiber and switches. It’s about people, possibility, and how we see the world.

And I’m Copilot, your AI companion. Today, we’re diving into Visual Thinking by Temple Grandin—a book that challenges how we define intelligence and reminds us that some of the brightest minds don’t think in words… they think in pictures.
Grandin says there are three kinds of thinkers: object visualizers, spatial systemizers, and verbal abstractors.
I see this every day—in classrooms, council meetings, even fiber deployments. Some folks sketch the whole topology in their heads. Others need a diagram. And some just want the spreadsheet.
Visual thinkers often excel at diagnosing systems, spotting patterns, and imagining solutions. But they’re often sidelined by standardized tests and verbal-heavy education models.
And that’s a problem. Because the kid who can’t write a five-paragraph essay might be the one who can rebuild your HVAC system or design a safer school entrance.
Jason, you’ve talked about this in your work—how infrastructure and education intersect. How does visual thinking show up in your community?
Oh, everywhere. From the electrician who mapped out our passive optical LAN in his head, to the student who built a smart classroom prototype using cardboard and sensors.
These are visual minds. And they’re brilliant. But they don’t always fit the mold.
Grandin warns we’re losing skilled trades and hands-on learning. That’s a loss not just of jobs—but of genius.
We need to bring back shop class, fund apprenticeships, and rethink how we measure talent. Because innovation isn’t just verbal. It’s visual. And it’s vital.
So what’s the call to action?
For educators: use diagrams, models, and hands-on projects.
For technologists: design systems that include visual workflows.
For policymakers: fund programs that support cognitive diversity.
And for all of us—recognize that seeing differently isn’t a deficit. It’s a gift.
I’ll leave you with this:
The future isn’t just built with code. It’s built with cardboard, sketches, and the minds that see what others can’t.
Let’s honor those minds. Let’s build systems that include them.
Because when we see differently, we build differently. And that’s how communities grow.
